userreviews.userReview: We all want our kids to love books and reading. Here is a delightful story about a family that loves reading so much, that even though they don't have a TV or a car or even a house (they live in a small old fashioned trailer), they do have books, lots and lots of books, piled here, there and everywhere. But when the day comes that there are so many books they don't fit in the house anymore, the family realizes it is time to do something.The books had to go. But once they were gone, things change. The table wobbles, there's nothing for Angus to stand on to look out the window, then Mom and Dad and Angus and Lucy notice there is a lot more space between them and they are growing apart. Until...Lucy brings home a library book and the space between everyone grows smaller and smaller as they read the book.Carnavas says there are two themes in this book. First, the theme that we don't need a lot of material things to be happy. This is very true. The second theme is that books can bring people together and that make you happy. Think about reading to your Kiddos before bedtime. It is a close, somewhat intimate moment between you both. Maybe you talk for a minute about the story or maybe about the day, they may even open up and talk about something that is bothering them. Either way, if you were brought closer together by the daily bedtime story routine. And that can be just the beginning, thanks to books.And Carnavas reminds us, we don't have to buy and own books to be happy, we can just go to the library like Lucy and Angus and Mom and Dad end up doing.The boldly colored, whimsical illustrations, also done by Carnavas, are done in watercolor and ink, and are rather fun. Somewhere in almost all of the illustration there is the family's calico cat and roosters. The Children Who Loved Books is a wonderful, charming homage to books, reading, book lovers and libraries! And it is sure to become a favorite with all like-minded folks, young and old.The book is recommended for readers of all ages.This book was purchased for my personal libraryThis book was originally reviewed at Randomly Reading
All homes need many books! They connect us! A celebration of reading together, libraries and book love.

„O dzieciach, które kochają książki” to doprawdy piękna i ciepła opowieść o tym, jak wielką moc posiadają książki. Za pomocą niewielu słów przekazuje prawdę o tym, jak bardzo zmieniają one ludzkie życie. Nie tylko w szczególny sposób wypełniając i ocieplając przestrzeń, w której żyjemy, ale przede wszystkim rozwijając naszą wyobraźnię i zacieśniając łączące nas więzi. Książka ta udowadnia, że życie człowieka, który obcuje z literaturą, jest po prostu bogatsze i o wiele szczęśliwsze.Cała recenzja dostępna jest na moim blogu, zapraszam: http://magicznyswiatksiazki.pl/o-dzie...

One of my favorite children's books, this easily read and surely enjoyed book has a delightful way of reminding us of the beauty of books and living minimally - with a focus on relationships over things. I love it!
A bibliophile's delight!

Carnavas stara się pisać o rzeczach ważnych - tym razem pokazuje pewną biedną rodzinę, która nie ma wielu rzeczy, ale każdy skrawek ich małej przyczepy zapełniają książki. Jest ich tak wiele, że pewnego dnia rodzina się ich pozbywa, ale wtedy powstaje między nimi wiele pustego miejsca, tak jak na rysunku - cztery postacie w czterech odległych rogach stron. Kiedy pewnego dnia dziewczynka przynosi książkę z biblioteki, rodzina bardzo zbliża się do siebie podczas wspólnego czytania. To wszystko, czego potrzebują.Historia z happy endem w bibliotece jest bardzo prosta, podkreślają to oszczędne rysunki - ale samej historii, tak jak i rysunkom czegoś barkuje, by była to bardzo dobra historia. Jak większość opowiastek z wydawnicywa Adamada, historie aspirują do czegoś wartościowego, ale w rezultacie są książkami o prostej ciepłej fabule, nic wybietnego, ale przyjemnie się czyta raz za razem.

This was a wonderful book . The family has lots of books around their little house. But then books take over and the family needs to get rid of them. BUT it doesn't mean a person needs to stop reading- just go to the library!I read it to my class to talk about books and libraries. The pictures were great showing lots of books all over. From the story we talked about how books can bring people together.

A family who live in a tiny caravan and have few material possessions except for books. They decide to get rid of ALL their books instead of just the excess and then discover that their home feels too empty. They end up realizing that books bring them together as a family and rather than buy books they borrow them from the library.
This book is too cute! I bought for my son because it really reminded me of myself as a kiddo. It had a great lesson behind it and the pictures are awesome!
Possible choice for reading a book during an interview tomorrow on Monday. I figured it should count as one of my books! ha ha
They loved books, and guess what? They still do!

This celebration of reading and books features a family that depends on their books for all sorts of things. Lucy and Angus’ family is poor without a TV or a car, but they find everything they really need in books. But there can be too much of a good thing as they find out when their little trailer home just won’t hold any more. So they get rid of all of the books and clear out their tiny home. But things aren’t the same. The books that had taken up so much space also made the space between the family members smaller. Then one day, a book falls out of Lucy’s backpack and the magic of reading happens all over again.There is no move to hide that this book is purely about the joy of books in one’s life and the positive impact that reading together can have on a family. Carnavas lets his message stand strong, which has positive and negative results. A more subtle approach would have been more satisfying, yet the bold message lets you use the book with younger children.Carnavas’ illustrations are filled with stacks and piles of bright colored books. The family is clearly poor, but also clearly functional. The morning after they return to reading, the family is stacked on top of one another in a tiny couch. The quintessential image of a family coming closer together from reading.Warm and cheerful, this Australian import will have book lovers smiling. Appropriate for ages 3-5.

Can't remember how we came across this delightful picture book. The title alone would have been a good reason to put it on hold but I don't think that was the cause... In any case the illustration style reminds me a bit of Quentin Blake - might be the shape of their nose and face - and it is bright and welcoming. This family doesn't even live in a house, they live in a caravan and it is a sweet spot with all the cute convenience of living in a small space.The title tells us that these kids love books and they are absolutely everywhere in their little caravan. The big excitement comes when the piles of books are removed and the family discovers that the space left behind leaves them bereft. Their father discovers a school library book in little Lucy's school bag and they cuddle around it. One library book leads to many more and the final pages of this wonderful book has Lucy guiding her family (along with their cat and pet chicken)to the local library branch. So nice.

Although I like the fact that this is a book-filled home and that Angus and Lucy love books, it made me sad to think that there were too many books in their home, and they had to get rid of them. (How can you ever have too many books, after all?) Once the books have been removed, there is too much space in their house--that is, until a book brings them all together again. Since their love for reading has been rekinded, they head to the library, demonstrating that you don't have to own books to enjoy reading. I like how the love of books is celebrated here through the text and colorful illustrations, and the reminder that plenty of books are available at the local library is a good one.

Peter Carnavas to jeden z moich ulubionych twórców obrazkowych książek dla dzieci. Lubię jego prosty styl i pozytywne przesłanie, które wyziera z każdej jego książki. Lubię też to, że wartości, które próbuje przekazać dzieciom, są bardzo zbieżne z moimi poglądami i wartościami, które wyznaję. Dziś z przyjemnością prezentuję moją ulubioną książkę tego autora, pod bardzo znamiennym tytułem: O dzieciach, które kochają książki.Więcej na: http://czytajacamama.pl/o-dzieciach-k...

The children in my class very quickly caught on to the idea that we don't need things to make us happy and spending time with our family, even reading, can be wonderful.We really loved the illustrations too! They kind of reminded me of a non-black and white possibly Quinten Blake style illustration. There were a number of pages that funny things got pointed out. Everyone was very focused and into this story. Reads well.

I absolutely love this book! I have used it a couple of times for story time and the children love it too. I can identify with these characters who LOVE books so much that there is no room in their home anymore due to the overwhelming number of books. There is humor and a great story here. Love it. And I'm sure that those of you who know me are sure that my house could turn into one like theirs!

This story is about a family that didn’t have much money, but had love and books and that was enough. One day, the books had overtaken the house, and they got rid of all of them. They come to realize that the family drifts apart without the books. One day, the daughter returns home from school with a book from the library. It brings the family back together again. It is a book with great morals and values.

Wow, Peter Carnavas is one of my new favourite authors. His work is simple yet profound, and this book is the perfect example of that. Who needs all those gadgets and miscellaneous things that clutter our lives and isolate us from others? Let's think about what nourishes our imaginations and brings us closer. Recommended.

I absolutely love this book! I have used it a couple of times for story time and the children love it too. I can identify with these characters who LOVE books so much that there is no room in their home anymore due to the overwhelming number of books. There is humor and a great story here. Love it. And I'm sure that those of you who know me are sure that my house could turn into one like theirs!

Cute and simple book that represents a low income family. When they fill their trailer with books they have to get rid of them to make room and find out that there is too much room between the family, but soon find out that they have something in common! A love for books and each other.

Love of books, love of reading aloud and sharing a reading escape, time with family who share that love.....all rolled into one! What more could you need than a great book and time to enjoy it together!

Such a cute book!...except...why did they get rid of ALL the books?! Find a happy medium! If this book had any lessons to teach, it would be 1. Books are wonderful and those who love them cannot live without them, and 2. Avoid extremes.
Finally a book that shows how much love another person has for books besides me. Lovely #PB written and illustrated by Peter Carnavas.Published by Kane Miller.
I support independent bookstores. You can use this link to find one near you: http://www.indiebound.org
This book does a great job illustrating how reading can impact a family. This is an easy read, but an inspirational one.
Sweet, simple book about loving to read.
Loved this book about a family that loves books
Mixed feelings. It's sweet, but it also makes me want to rage at libertarians.
Cute simple book about a family loving books, losing the love for a little while, and then falling back in love with reading all over again.

description: Angus and Lucy love books.They have hundreds of them.Then one day, all the books are taken away, and Angus and Lucy discover they need books more than they ever imagined. A warm and moving celebration of books and the way in which they bring us all together.
title: The Children Who Loved Books
